TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit XhtmlMobileTextWriter extends System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.MobileTextWriter

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("The System.Web.Mobile.dll assembly has been deprecated and should no longer be used. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=157231.")

Docs.summary: Provides text writer functionality for devices targeted by the XHTML adapter set, including Extensible Hypertext Markup Language (XHTML), XHTML Mobile, and Wireless Markup Language (WML). For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks XHTML is an XML-compliant markup that is based on HTML 4.1 and allows you to create Web sites suitable for multiple device types. It merges HTML's ease of use with XML's strict element guidelines to produce a markup language with a wide range of format and style options and reduced markup tag ambiguity. This class provides formatting capabilities that ASP.NET server controls use when rendering XHTML content to clients. The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter> renders markup that meets the standards of three different XHTML doc types: XHTML Basic, which supports limited style and format elements; XHTML Mobile Profile, which supports inline style sheets; and WML 2.0, which is based on XHTML 1.1 and supports cascading style sheets.
This class is used primarily by developers of custom mobile page and control adapters.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter> class can render all HTML elements, attributes, and style attributes, but, unlike the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter> class, does not allow title capitalization of these markup elements.
An <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlPageAdapter> instantiates an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter> and depending on the capabilities of the target device, initializes a number of properties, such as <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter.SupportsNoWrapStyle%2A>, <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter.SuppressNewLine%2A>, and <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter.UseDivsForBreaks%2A>, that assist the text writer in rendering the page and its controls.
Your adapter can use a variety of methods to apply styles and control formatting:
- <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter.EnterStyle%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter.ExitStyle%2A>,
- <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter.EnterLayout%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter.ExitLayout%2A>, and
- <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter.EnterFormat%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter.ExitFormat%2A>.
> [!NOTE] > This class derives from the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.MobileTextWriter> class, which in turn derives from the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.MultiPartWriter> class, and much of its functionality is provided by these base classes.
You can use the members of this class, and any members it inherits from the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.MobileTextWriter> class, to create custom text writers to use in a custom XHTML page or in class adapters. You can also create new derived classes that override the standard behavior of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter> class.
Device filtering is required in order to use a specific adapter or text writer for a server control. For more information about device filtering, see [Architectural Overview of Adaptive Control Behavior](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/4ff05ae9-4109-4352-929e-ad893895dbff(v=vs.100)) and [Device Filtering Overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/bdfeaa58-dedd-4c0d-8610-988aac0eff19(v=vs.100)).

Docs.permission: for operating in a hosted environment. Demand value: ; Permission value: .

Architectural Overview of Adaptive Control Behavior

remarks.format:
## Remarks Text writers are instantiated by a corresponding page adapter for a specific target device, and then used by the page adapter and the adapters for each control on the page.
This class is used primarily by developers of custom mobile page and control adapters.

Docs.related: ASP.NET and XHTML Compliance
Architectural Overview of Adaptive Control Behavior

Docs.param: The name of a variable to be embedded in a page.
Docs.summary: Adds a provided variable name to a list of variables to be embedded in pages for WML devices. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Certain WML devices require a `<wml:onevent>` element to provide information for postback.
WML devices provide limited functionality for navigation and postback, and require WML commands and variables to be written to the page.
This method is used primarily by developers of custom mobile page and control adapters.
## Examples When rendering the page, the following `<wml:onevent>` structure might be included in the page's markup:
`<wml:onevent type="onenterforward">`
`<wml:refresh>`
`<wmlsetvar name="buttonSaveClicked" />`
`<wmlsetvar name="nextPage" value="3" />`
`</wml:refresh>`
`</wml:onevent>`
Depending on the user's actions, the values might be modified by scripts on the page to return the following structure on postback:
`<wml:onevent type="onenterforward">`
`<wml:refresh>`
`<wmlsetvar name="buttonSaveClicked" value="true" />`
`<wmlsetvar name="nextPage" value="9" />`
`</wml:refresh>`
`</wml:onevent>`

Docs.related: ASP.NET and XHTML Compliance
Architectural Overview of Adaptive Control Behavior

remarks.format:
## Remarks Certain WML 2.0 devices require a WML `<wml:onevent>` element to provide information for postback.
WML devices provide limited functionality for navigation and postback, and require WML commands and variables to be written to the page.
This method is used primarily by developers of custom mobile page and control adapters.
## Examples When rendering the page, the following `<wml:onevent>` structure might be included in the page's markup:
`<wml:onevent type="onenterforward">`
`<wml:refresh>`
`<wmlsetvar name="buttonSaveClicked" />`
`<wmlsetvar name="nextPage" value="3" />`
`</wml:refresh>`
`</wml:onevent>`
Depending on the user's actions, the values might be modified by scripts on the page to return the following structure on postback:
`<wml:onevent type="onenterforward">`
`<wml:refresh>`
`<wmlsetvar name="buttonSaveClicked" value="true" />`
`<wmlsetvar name="nextPage" value="9" />`
`</wml:refresh>`
`</wml:onevent>`

Docs.related: ASP.NET and XHTML Compliance
Architectural Overview of Adaptive Control Behavior

Docs.summary: Gets the unique key used to retrieve items from the . This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Some devices do not allow inline styles in elements, but require style information to be provided from a linked style sheet. If the linked style sheet is stored in the <xref:System.Web.Caching.Cache>, the URL contains a unique <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter.CacheKey%2A> that identifies the style sheet to return. For these target devices, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter> moves style information from rendered controls to a style sheet for caching.
A page adapter can instruct the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter> to save the style sheet in the <xref:System.Web.Caching.Cache> using <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter.SetCacheKey%2A>, or in the <xref:System.Web.HttpContext.Session%2A> using <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter.SetSessionKey%2A> before rendering the page.
This property is used primarily by developers of custom mobile page and control adapters.

## Remarks If <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlMobileTextWriter.BeginCachedRendering%2A> has been called, the `style` is set as the current style, and a beginning `<span>` element that implements the style is written to the output stream.
This method is used primarily by developers of custom mobile page and control adapters.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property must be initialized by the page adapter, and is used primarily by developers of custom mobile page and control adapters.

Docs.param: The name of the attribute.
The value for the attribute.
If , the value is encoded before being written.
Docs.summary: Writes an attribute and its value to the current element using the provided attribute and value, and encodes the value if specified. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If the value is `null` or an empty string, no attribute is written because XHTML requires that all attributes have values.
This method is used primarily by developers of custom mobile page and control adapters.

Docs.related: ASP.NET and XHTML Compliance
Architectural Overview of Adaptive Control Behavior

Docs.param: The markup element to write to the output stream.
Docs.summary: Writes any tab spacing and the opening tag of the specified markup element to the output stream. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If there is a pending break, is `false`, and the provided tag is not a block element (such as `

`, `

`, `
    `, or ``), which automatically break before and after the element, the method is called before writing the beginning tag. This method is used primarily by developers of custom mobile page and control adapters.

Docs.related: ASP.NET and XHTML Compliance
Architectural Overview of Adaptive Control Behavior

` tag or a `
` structure. This method is used primarily by developers of custom mobile page and control adapters.

Docs.param: A value indicating the type of declaration to write.
Docs.summary: Writes a declaration that is unique to target devices represented by the provided value. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The page adapter calls this method, and depending on the `type`, writes the following document type declarations:
|Type|Description| |----------|-----------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.Doctype.XhtmlBasic>|\<\!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML Basic 1.0//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml-basic/xhtml-basic10.dtd">| |<xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.Doctype.XhtmlMobileProfile>|\<\!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//WAPFORUM//DTD XHTML Mobile 1.0//EN" "http://www.wapforum.org/DTD/xhtml-mobile10.dtd">| |<xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.Doctype.Wml20>|\<\!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//WAPFORUM//DTD WML 2.0//EN" "http://www.wapforum.org/dtd/wml20.dtd">|
This method is used primarily by developers of custom mobile page and control adapters.

Docs.related: ASP.NET and XHTML Compliance
Architectural Overview of Adaptive Control Behavior

Docs.param: A string containing the name of the URL parameter.
A string containing the value of the URL parameter.
Docs.summary: Writes an encoded URL, which includes a query-string parameter, to the output stream. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Both the name of the parameter and the URL value are encoded, and an equal sign (=) is inserted between them. Spaces in the `name` or `value` strings are encoded as plus signs (+), and equal signs (=) are encoded as %3d.

Docs.related: ASP.NET and XHTML Compliance
Architectural Overview of Adaptive Control Behavior

Docs.summary: Writes an XML declaration along with the current document encoding value. This API is obsolete. For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see Mobile Apps & Sites with ASP.NET.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If the current encoding is UTF-8, the declaration output would be:
`<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>`

Docs.related: ASP.NET and XHTML Compliance
Architectural Overview of Adaptive Control Behavior
